Jump squats are bodyweight exercises characterized by leaping directly upwards at the top of the movement. With proper form, jump squats can be a great way to burn calories and improve strength in both your upper body and lower body.
Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward. Keep your back straight, chest lifted, and engage your core muscles.

Lower your body into a squat position by bending at the hips and knees. Push your hips back as if you are sitting into a chair, while keeping your weight on your heels. Aim to lower your thighs parallel to the ground or slightly below.
Once you\'ve reached the squat position, swiftly and explosively jump up as high as you can. Extend your legs fully and engage your core and glute muscles to generate power.
As you land, focus on maintaining a soft landing by bending your knees and hips to absorb the impact. Land with your knees slightly bent to cushion the landing.
Immediately after landing, go back into the squat position and repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Push-ups are an exercise in which a person, keeping a prone position, with the hands palms down under the shoulders, the balls of the feet on the ground, and the back straight, pushes the body up and lets it down by an alternate straightening and bending of the arms.

Begin by positioning yourself face down on the floor or a mat. Place your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, fingers pointing forward. Extend your legs straight behind you, toes on the ground, and engage your core muscles.
Make sure your hands are directly under your shoulders, and your arms are fully extended. Your palms should be flat on the ground, pressing into the floor.
Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. Avoid arching or sagging your lower back.
Lower yourself until your chest is a few inches above the ground. Your elbows should be at approximately a 45-degree angle to your body.
Push through your palms, straightening your elbows and returning to the starting position. Keep your body straight throughout the movement, avoiding any sagging or excessive arching.
Complete the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

The bicep curl with dumbbells is an exercise that targets the biceps muscles of the upper arm. It involves flexing the elbow joint to lift dumbbells towards the shoulders while keeping the upper arms stationary. The exercise primarily isolates the biceps and helps develop strength, size, and definition in the upper arm muscles.
Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended down by your sides. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart, your back straight, and your core engaged.
Grasp the dumbbells with an underhand grip (palms facing upward). Your grip should be firm, with your hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

Keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders. As you lift the dumbbells, focus on contracting your biceps and avoid any swinging or using momentum to lift the weights. Continue lifting until the dumbbells are at shoulder level, or you feel a good contraction in your biceps. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement to maximize the muscle engagement.

Inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, with your arms fully extended. Maintain control throughout the lowering phase, resisting the urge to let the weights drop quickly.
Repeat the curling and lowering phases for the desired number of repetitions. Focus on maintaining proper form, control, and a slow and controlled tempo throughout the exercise.
